clusters.title: Ousted Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death
clusters.neutral_headline: Bangladesh Ex-Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina Sentenced to Death
bullet_summary: Hasina, who was sentenced in absentia after fleeing to India, was found guilty of crimes against humanity
Former Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina was found guilty of crimes against humanity during last year's student protests and was sentenced to death over a deadly repression against protestors,
A special tribunal in Bangladesh’s Dhaka has found former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina guilty of crimes against humanity

items.content: Former Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has been sentenced to death over a deadly crackdown on anti-government protests last year.

items.title: Ousted Bangladesh PM Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death for crimes against humanity
items.standfirst: Hasina sentenced in absentia by court in Dhaka over deadly crackdown on student-led uprising last yearBangladesh’s deposed prime minister Sheikh Hasina has been sentenced to death in absentia by a court in Dhaka for crimes against humanity over a deadly crackdown on a student-led uprising last year.A three-judge bench of the country’s international crimes tribunal convicted Hasina of crimes including incitement, orders to kill and inaction to prevent atrocities, as she oversaw a crackdown on anti-government protesters last year. Continue reading...
items.content: Hasina sentenced in absentia by court in Dhaka over deadly crackdown on student-led uprising last yearBangladesh’s deposed prime minister Sheikh Hasina has been sentenced to death in absentia by a court in Dhaka for crimes against humanity over a deadly crackdown on a student-led uprising last year.A three-judge bench of the country’s international crimes tribunal convicted Hasina of crimes including incitement, orders to kill and inaction to prevent atrocities, as she oversaw a crackdown on anti-government protesters last year. Continue reading...

items.title: Bangladesh's ousted leader Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death for crimes against humanity
items.standfirst: A court in Bangladesh on Monday sentenced ousted prime minister Sheikh Hasina to death for ordering a deadly crackdown on student-led protests last year. Hasina, who was sentenced in absentia after fleeing to India, was found guilty of crimes against humanity. France24 correspondent Navodita Kumari reports the latest from New Delhi, India.
items.content: A court in Bangladesh on Monday sentenced ousted prime minister Sheikh Hasina to death for ordering a deadly crackdown on student-led protests last year. Hasina, who was sentenced in absentia after fleeing to India, was found guilty of crimes against humanity. France24 correspondent Navodita Kumari reports the latest from New Delhi, India.

ai_summary: Sheikh Hasina was sentenced to death in absentia by a Dhaka court.
The court found her guilty of crimes against humanity during protests.
The charges stemmed from a crackdown on student-led uprisings last year.
Hasina fled to India and was tried in absentia after the uprising.
The court's decision was described as politically motivated by Hasina.

items.title: Trump now tells Republicans to vote to release Epstein files
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Sunday urged his fellow Republicans in Congress to vote for the release of files related to the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, despite previously opposing the move. Trump wrote on Truth Social that “we have nothing to hide”, while accusing Democrats of fuelling an “Epstein hoax” over newly surfaced emails. Ellen Gainsford reports.

clusters.title: US attacks another alleged drug boat in Pacific, killing three, as Trump signals possible talks with Maduro

items.title: US attacks another alleged drug boat in Pacific, killing three, as Trump signals possible talks with Maduro
items.standfirst: Strike comes as navy’s most advanced aircraft carrier arrives in Caribbean Sea and president says US may open talks with Venezuelan leaderThe United States conducted another attack on an alleged drug trafficking boat in the eastern Pacific on Saturday, killing three people aboard, the Pentagon said on Sunday.“Intelligence confirmed that the vessel was involved in illicit narcotics smuggling, transiting along a known narco-trafficking route, and carrying narcotics,” the US Southern Command announced in a post on social media. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Trump hints at possible talks with Maduro as US ramps up pressure on Venezuela
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump said on Sunday the United States “may be having some discussions” with Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro, signalling a possible diplomatic opening as Washington expands its military presence near Venezuela. The arrival of the world's largest aircraft carrier as part of a US counterdrug operation has raised concerns of escalating pressure tactics.

clusters.title: Voters in Ecuador reject return of foreign military bases
clusters.neutral_headline: Ecuador Votes Against Allowing Foreign Military Bases
bullet_summary: Ecuadorans on Sunday rejected the return of US military bases, early referendum results showed, dealing a setback to Trump-aligned President Daniel Noboa
Reported by France24, Reuters Top News, BBC World and others

items.title: Voters in Ecuador reject return of foreign military bases
items.standfirst: Ecuador has voted to reject the return of US military bases to the country, in a referendum on Sunday. On the ballot there was also a vote to cut funding for political parties and a separate measure to rewrite the country's constitution, which were both likewise voted down. Ellen Gainsford reports.
items.content: Ecuador has voted to reject the return of US military bases to the country, in a referendum on Sunday. On the ballot there was also a vote to cut funding for political parties and a separate measure to rewrite the country's constitution, which were both likewise voted down. Ellen Gainsford reports.

items.title: Blow to US Plans To Revive Bases in Latin America

items.content: Voters have rejected a referendum proposal, dealing a blow to President Daniel Noboa and US ambitions in the region.

items.title: Ecuador rejects return of US military bases in major setback for President Noboa
items.standfirst: Ecuadorans on Sunday rejected the return of US military bases, early referendum results showed, dealing a setback to Trump-aligned President Daniel Noboa. With more than half the ballots counted, about 60 percent of voters opposed lifting the country’s long-standing ban on hosting foreign military facilities.
items.content: Ecuadorans on Sunday rejected the return of US military bases, early referendum results showed, dealing a setback to Trump-aligned President Daniel Noboa. With more than half the ballots counted, about 60 percent of voters opposed lifting the country’s long-standing ban on hosting foreign military facilities.

clusters.title: Communist and far-right candidates head to Chile presidential run-off
clusters.neutral_headline: Chile Heads to Run-Off Election Between Jara and Kast
bullet_summary: Chile’s former labor minister Jeannette Jara and far-right leader Jose Antonio Kast will face a presidential run-off after leading Sunday’s first-round vote, provisional results showed
Reported by BBC World, France24, Guardian World and others

items.title: Communist and far-right candidates head to Chile presidential run-off
items.standfirst: The Communist Party's Jeanette Jara will face far-right candidate José Antonio Kast in the second round of voting in December.
items.content: The Communist Party's Jeanette Jara will face far-right candidate José Antonio Kast in the second round of voting in December.

items.title: Crime-weary Chile sends leftist Jara and far-right Kast to presidential run-off
items.standfirst: Chile’s former labor minister Jeannette Jara and far-right leader Jose Antonio Kast will face a presidential run-off after leading Sunday’s first-round vote, provisional results showed. With 82.97% counted, Jara had 26.71% and Kast 24.12%. The campaign has been dominated by rising violent crime blamed on foreign gangs.
items.content: Chile’s former labor minister Jeannette Jara and far-right leader Jose Antonio Kast will face a presidential run-off after leading Sunday’s first-round vote, provisional results showed. With 82.97% counted, Jara had 26.71% and Kast 24.12%. The campaign has been dominated by rising violent crime blamed on foreign gangs.

items.title: Crime-weary Chile sends leftist Jara and far-right Kast to presidential run-off
items.standfirst: Chile’s former labor minister Jeannette Jara and far-right leader Jose Antonio Kast will face a presidential run-off after leading Sunday’s first-round vote, provisional results showed. With 82.97 percent of the vote counted, Jara had 26.71 percent and Kast 24.12 percent. The campaign has been dominated by rising violent crime blamed on foreign gangs.
items.content: Chile’s former labor minister Jeannette Jara and far-right leader Jose Antonio Kast will face a presidential run-off after leading Sunday’s first-round vote, provisional results showed. With 82.97 percent of the vote counted, Jara had 26.71 percent and Kast 24.12 percent. The campaign has been dominated by rising violent crime blamed on foreign gangs.

items.title: Far-right candidate José Antonio Kast favourite to become Chile’s next president after first round vote
items.standfirst: The ultraconservative lawyer is in pole position going into the second round election, after running a campaign with a distinctly Trumpian feel​The ultraconservative lawyer, José Antonio Kast, is in pole position to become Chile’s next leader after advancing to the second round of the South American country’s presidential election where he will face the Communist party candidate Jeannette Jara.With more than 70% of votes counted, Kast had secured about 24% of the vote in Sunday’s first round vote, having campaigned on hard-line promises to crack down on crime and immigration, while making a Donald Trump-style pledge to “put Chileans first”. Continue reading...
items.content: The ultraconservative lawyer is in pole position going into the second round election, after running a campaign with a distinctly Trumpian feel​The ultraconservative lawyer, José Antonio Kast, is in pole position to become Chile’s next leader after advancing to the second round of the South American country’s presidential election where he will face the Communist party candidate Jeannette Jara.With more than 70% of votes counted, Kast had secured about 24% of the vote in Sunday’s first round vote, having campaigned on hard-line promises to crack down on crime and immigration, while making a Donald Trump-style pledge to “put Chileans first”. Continue reading...

items.content: Leftist former Labour Minister Jeannette Jara and far-right leader Jose Antonio Kast set to face off in December run-off

items.title: Chile votes for next president in contest dominated by crime and migration fears
items.standfirst: Voters face seemingly extreme choice between communist and rightwing frontrunners, who both promise to fight foreign gangsChileans began voting for a new president and parliament on Sunday, in a contest expected to favour the hard right as candidates play on popular fears over organised crime and immigration.It is the first of an expected two rounds of presidential elections, as polls show none of the candidates clearing the 50% threshold needed to avoid a runoff scheduled for 14 December. Continue reading...
items.content: Voters face seemingly extreme choice between communist and rightwing frontrunners, who both promise to fight foreign gangsChileans began voting for a new president and parliament on Sunday, in a contest expected to favour the hard right as candidates play on popular fears over organised crime and immigration.It is the first of an expected two rounds of presidential elections, as polls show none of the candidates clearing the 50% threshold needed to avoid a runoff scheduled for 14 December. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Jeannette Jara and Jose Antonio Kast will face a run-off election.
They led the first-round vote in Chile's presidential election.
Jara is from the Communist Party, Kast is far-right.
The campaign focused on rising violent crime in Chile.
Kast campaigned with promises to crack down on crime.

clusters.title: How women over 30 are rewriting the single mom narrative in America
clusters.neutral_headline: Women Over 30 Rewrite Single Mom Narrative

items.title: How women over 30 are rewriting the single mom narrative in America
items.standfirst: Forty percent of babies in the U.S. are born to unmarried mothers. Increasingly, those moms are over 30, at a time when teen pregnancy has fallen off a cliff and births are declining for younger women. (Image credit: Maansi Srivastava)
items.content: Forty percent of babies in the U.S. are born to unmarried mothers. Increasingly, those moms are over 30, at a time when teen pregnancy has fallen off a cliff and births are declining for younger women. (Image credit: Maansi Srivastava)

items.standfirst: Forty percent of babies in the U.S. are born to unmarried mothers. Increasingly, those moms are over 30, at a time when teen pregnancy has fallen off a cliff and births are declining for younger women.
items.content: Forty percent of babies in the U.S. are born to unmarried mothers. Increasingly, those moms are over 30, at a time when teen pregnancy has fallen off a cliff and births are declining for younger women.(Image credit: Maansi Srivastava)

ai_summary: Forty percent of US babies are born to unmarried mothers.
Increasingly, these mothers are over the age of thirty.
Teen pregnancy has significantly decreased.
Births are declining for younger women.
The narrative is changing for single mothers.

items.title: Nigerian Startups Shun Local IPOs as Weak Naira Deters Founders
Nigerian Startups Shun Local IPOs as Weak Naira Deters Founders
items.standfirst: Nigerian startups have stayed away from listing on a special section of the country’s stock exchange because of the local currency’s weakness, according to a survey of the new companies.
items.content: Nigerian startups have stayed away from listing on a special section of the country’s stock exchange because of the local currency’s weakness, according to a survey of the new companies.

ai_summary: Nigerian startups are avoiding local IPOs.
The local currency's weakness is a deterrent.

Startups are staying away from a special section.
The Naira's weakness is impacting the market.

items.standfirst: Castle Water says restructuring plans do not go far enough and extra funds will help resolve pollution crisisBusiness live – latest updatesA bidder for Thames Water has said it would inject £1bn more into the struggling utility company than rival proposals if it gained control.John Reynolds, the chief executive of the independent water retailer Castle Water, said the current plans under discussion with creditors to rebuild Thames Water’s finances does not go far enough and does not properly address its environmental crisis. The bidder is Castle Water.
They believe current plans do not go far enough.
The funds would help resolve the pollution crisis.
The offer is in response to restructuring plans.

clusters.title: ‘Gen Z’ protests in Mexico City takes aim at country’s crime and corruption
clusters.neutral_headline: Gen Z Protests in Mexico City Against Crime
bullet_summary: Reported by NBC World, Sky News World

items.title: ‘Gen Z’ protests in Mexico City takes aim at country’s crime and corruption
items.standfirst: Thousands protest crime and corruption in Mexico City demonstrations organized by members of Generation Z. Similar protests have taken place in several countries this year, including Nepal, which led to the resignation of its prime minister.
items.content: Thousands protest crime and corruption in Mexico City demonstrations organized by members of Generation Z. Similar protests have taken place in several countries this year, including Nepal, which led to the resignation of its prime minister.

items.title: Thousands march in Gen Z protests against crime and corruption in Mexico
items.standfirst: Thousands have taken to the streets of Mexico City to protest against crime and corruption - with 120 people left injured, according to authorities.
items.content: Thousands have taken to the streets of Mexico City to protest against crime and corruption - with 120 people left injured, according to authorities.

ai_summary: Gen Z organized protests in Mexico City.
The protests targeted crime and corruption.
Thousands participated in the demonstrations.
Similar protests occurred in other countries.
Authorities reported 120 injuries.
